item.title: Dr. robot could conduct your next surgery
item.description: Scientists have shown the first use of autonomous robots to conduct bowel surgery under supervision, paving the way for robots one day taking the lead in the operating room.
item.ExtractedText: 1 of 10 10 photos: Why your next hotel will be staffed by robots Henn-na Hotel, Japan – Robot hotel workers are already a reality. The Henn-na Hotel in Sasebo, Japan opened in 2015. Hide Caption 2 of 10 10 photos: Why your next hotel will be staffed by robots Job killers? – The rise of the robots has sparked concerns that machines could put travel and tourism workers out of jobs. Dinosaurs are probably safe. Hide Caption 3 of 10 10 photos: Why your next hotel will be staffed by robots Who's running the show? – Travelzoo's European president, Richard Singer, points out that the Japanese robot hotel has humans working behind the scene. "I would be very surprised if we get to the point where hotels are entirely manned by robots." Hide Caption 4 of 10 10 photos: Why your next hotel will be staffed by robots Heavy lifting – Oxford University's Carl Benedikt Frey says some jobs are more at risk of robot replacement than others. Tour guides and hotel porters might find themselves in the firing line, others in the industry could benefit from technology. Hide Caption 5 of 10 10 photos: Why your next hotel will be staffed by robots Mario – Pictured here with one of his developers, Fabrice Goffin of Belgium's Zora Robotics, Mario is a small robot who began life as a health worker but is now being used in hotels. Hide Caption 6 of 10 10 photos: Why your next hotel will be staffed by robots Ghent Marriott – Mario helps welcome guests to the Ghent Marriott in Belgium. He speaks multiple languages and -- unlike humans -- can make PowerPoint presentations interesting. Hide Caption 7 of 10 10 photos: Why your next hotel will be staffed by robots Dance moves – Like his healthcare colleagues, Mario never fails to raise a smile, says Ghent Marriott General Manager Roger Langhout. He says the robot won't put anyone out of a job. Hide Caption 8 of 10 10 photos: Why your next hotel will be staffed by robots More robots to come – These robots were a novelty installation in a Japanese Sheraton, but plenty of more practical robots are on the way. A Travelzoo survey suggests two thirds of us are happy to be looked after by machines. Hide Caption 9 of 10 10 photos: Why your next hotel will be staffed by robots Booze bots – Robot bartenders are already at work, serving drinks on several Royal Caribbean cruise ships. The good news: no tips. The bad news: computer stats showing exactly how much you've drunk. Hide Caption
